title: Phil Neville not worried for his job, calling Brazil defeat 'one of the Lionesses' best performances'
text:
Phil Neville insists he "does not feel vulnerable" in the England job despite his team enduring their worst run in seven years.

The last time England had zero wins from five games the manager, Hope Powell, was sacked. Albeit that was during a major tournament - the 2013 Euros - but the Lionesses' 2-1 loss to Brazil on Saturday is nonetheless worrying.

It was a fourth loss from five games, during which they have conceded 11 goals, and Neville has come under increasing pressure to answer for his underperforming side. But as they approached tonight’s friendly in Portugal, the head coach denied feeling insecure, even saying the pressure was what his team needed.

But as they approached Wednesday night's friendly in Portugal the head coach denied feeling insecure in any way, even claiming that this pressure is what his team "needs".

"I don’t feel vulnerable at all. I was a coach at Manchester United and four games [after manager David Moyes got sacked] I left. I’m not the kind of manager that hangs around waiting for a pay out - I want this team to do well, win the Olympics and win Euro 2021," Neville said.

"We are in an era now - we saw it in the Premier League this week - you lose two or three games and all of a sudden people are calling for your head. This might be what we need - a kick up the backside. Can they have the resilience to get through under pressure?"
description: Phil Neville insists he "does not feel vulnerable" in the England job despite his team enduring their worst run in seven years.
